reviews.review_text: Darksiders 2 is probably one of my favorite aRPGs in recent years/ Althought the Deathinitive Edition does currently have some performance issues, the support that Nordic Games offered for Red Faction: Guerilla makes me optimistic that they will continue to work with the community and patch it to work properly.  I enjoyed the original Darksiders, but the sequel expands and improves on every aspect. Some quick comments.  - The graphics are indeed much improved. Crisp, clean, and the cel-shaded inspired art style is lovely with the overhauled lighting.  -The music, as in the original version of this game, is outstanding, and easily some of Jesper Kyd's best work. Equal parts gothic and celtic inspirations make the soundtrack well worth remembering.  -The voice acting, and the characterization of Death in particular, is exceptional. My biggest issue with the original Darksiders was that War was basically a grimdark Space Marine. Death, on the other hand, is always handy with a bit of much needed snark, sarcasm, and even the occasional moment of sensitivity. This is the reaper as I like to envision him.  - The gameplay is quick, satisfyingly punchy, and has a gentle learning curve with a high plateau. Playing with various specs and active abilities is quite enjoyable, and finding an upgrade for your equipment is always nice.  Overall, I would wholeheartedly recommend the Deathinitive Edition for newcomers to the series. For anyone who already owns and has played the original release of the game, you will not find anything new here, but revisiting a fine game in revised form is very enjoyable.

Very colorful graphics, beautiful and different worlds, artistic backgrounds.   Full voice dialogues, but they are a lot and after some time they become monotonous. However, they can be skipped.   Very good sound effects and amazing soundtrack, especially on boss-fights. By the way, some of the bosses are pretty awesome.   Similar gameplay with Darksiders 1, BUT you have to get used to the camera. It is not so free to control like in the first game. There will be many frustrating moments with bad perspectives and confusing movement. Therefore, you will fall from various cliffs a lot, until you figure out how to control your character effectively on each difficult spot.   You can earn XP, level up and get skills, different weapons and armor. Very large quantity of items. It feels like playing a MMORPG. Also, some weapons have special abilities.   Many skills and some of them are similar with Darksiders 1.   Each world has main areas and each one has a number of similar puzzles to be solved. So, the gameplay may feel repetitive after some time.   Huge campaign. The story continues from Darksiders 1, but with different character.   Death doesn't look so cool as War from the first game.   Again, boring secret items to collect and you'll have to visit again all areas searching.   There is also an arena, where you can fight various battles for bonuses. Grinding like hell, as you have to fight around 100 times to finish it. Reminds MMO as mentioned before, but it's so tiring and adds to the negativity of the repetitive gameplay.   PS. Death can do parkour? LoL :b

Darksiders 2 is a great Action-Adventure with RPG elements. The apocalyptic rider 'Death' is on an epic journey to proof his brother 'war' unguilty. During his journey he visits several places, the creators forge, the realm of the dead and other mystic locations.  The gameplay is like a combination of the old Tomb Raiders (1-3) Castlevania, and Lords of the Fallen. Challenging boss fights, climbing adventures and artifacts collecting makes fun for many hours. This game became one of my alltime favourites in a very short time.  Rating: Graphic 8.5/10 Sound 9/10 Gameplay 10/10

In the previous game you played as the Horseman War. This time around you play as Death, one of the remaining three riders of the Apocalypse and, parallel to the events of the first game, you will do your best to find a way to absolve War of his supposed crimes.  Darksiders II offers similar gameplay as its predecessor at its core. However, this time around the designers and developers wanted to go bigger and a bit more complex. As a result, the game offers a much larger world, RPG-like character progression with skill trees and an RPG-like inventory system. Apart from Death's main mission, you will get a chance to solve a few sidequests as well and reap some additional rewards from them too.  The action is still as fun as it was in the first Darksiders and Death has some pretty nice moves himself. It's just a shame the spectacular gory finishers aren't as present in this game as they were in the first, but are tied to a specific weapon stat.  Even though the composer is different, the music is still excellent, handled this time around by Jesper Kyd - a name people who played most of the Hitman games and the first two Assassin's Creed games might recognize.  While Darksiders II is still a very good action adventure game, if I had to pick which of the two I enjoyed more, I would have to go with the first Darksiders. Most of the flaws that affect this choice aren't that big, but put together they result in a slightly worse impression for me.   This game does offer a larger world, but the switch from a ruined, post-apocalyptic Earth to four completely different worlds as the main setting also caused it to lose some of its charm. The bigger issue, in fact, is that looking at each of these four larger distinct worlds individually - their subsections are not as interesting, detailed and visually diverse as the various sections the first Darksiders offered in a single world. They also often feel as if they were made that big simply to justify the ability to ride your horse (you are a  Horseman  of the Apocalypse after all) and are rather empty as a result.  Several sidequests are tied to (a tediously high number of) various collectibles and are not that interesting. On the other hand, for a game that tries to go down the RPG lane, it offers too few sidequests for such a large open world - this contributes to that feeling that the world is a bit empty. In general, I feel that trying to add more RPG elements and going with a bigger world at any cost didn't do Darksiders that many favors (as much as I love RPGs).  There are many other tiny nitpicks I could name, but I will skip them in favor of one big problem - bugs! The first Darksiders was quite polished (apart from the Steam achievement thing, which becomes a non-issue once you know about it). This game, however, has quite a few bugs. At random points after prolonged play the sound will stop working and will not go back to normal until you restart the game. Using the Steam overlay will cause the controls to stop responding at a random point and the game will act as if in a paused state, fixed only by going back to the main menu and reloading your save. The horseriding is a lot more clumsy and you may end up having to dismount to get unstuck. At rare occasions you may also end up stuck inside a wall, causing you to reload your save game. These are just a few of the most annoying issues I encountered and I am really surprised they weren't addressed for the Deathinitive Edition.  Despite the amount of text I spent talking about the flaws of this game, I still highly recommend it, just not as highly as the first Darksiders game. Still, if you can get past the bugs and some other potential flaws, you will have quite a bit of fun with Darksiders II.

LIKE PORTAL: open a portal here, and one over there. go through one to come out the other. use this to get to certain areas unreachable. also use this to solve puzzles. similar to portal 1 and 2.  LIKE DIABLO: kill enemies and pick up new weapons gear, cash, etc. level up and use skill points just like diablo.  upgrade weapons, abilities, etc. buy new comboes, and other upgrades, etc  game is pretty open, i wanna say it's open world.   PROS: amazing graphics! great story upgrading system battle system is great visuals/scenery is cool looking open world secret areas with special items boss fights etc  CONS: beat the entire game, no cons, no bugs, no glitches.  i rate this 9.9 out of 10 ;)

Gameplay TBH I expected more combat, like in Devil May Cry. I'm disappointed it's actually more of a parkour Zelda, but that's nothing against the game. Hunting the chests is fun. The dungeons and puzzles are well designed so far. Scaling walls and mastering the climbing is rewarded. I'm wary about backtracking. I hate intended backtracking. The world design lead me straight to an interesting dungeon I had no business attempting. It turns out the boss in there is an optional bounty, intended for characters lv6-12. I was barely level 2. I barely knew I or enemies _had_ levels yet. Yup. It's by the first cool merchant in the open world, and entices you with a chest. Why? Just block it off with an NPC or the hooks that already made me skip several chests.  Combat is fairly rewarding. Small groups of mooks are frequent and trivial, but that's expected. So far the boss fights have been neat and somewhat unique. As easy as it is to just mash light and heavy attack, encounters start to take some thought about dodge direction and how to utilize your active skills. So far most encounters are small and short. Maybe that will change. I'm not far.  This all said, it's fun and I probably will play it through. Secondary weapons seem to somewhat matter. Loot is cool. The demonic weapon upgrading is neat. The skill tree seems decent. I like you can respec, but it has a low-reasonable currency cost. Some old posts online imply you can actually have a 'build' by the end between the trees and gear. Not all solo ARPGs let you differentiate that much.  Graphics I'm impressed. It looks and runs great. I like the art style a lot. The first ice boss has a cool model and looked sharp. In game looks better than the video, more like the provided screenshots. I'm not experiencing the performance issues that generated most of the negative reviews. I assume they've been fixed. That said, I'm < 6hrs in as of this review.  Controls/Mechanics Combat is smooth. Lock-on could have been a toggle instead of a hold, but it's fine. I would have preferred trigger+button for assigned powers over bumber+button, but also fine. As much as I love the look and idea of the horse, I wish they would have just given a sprint. The horse is allowed in very limited locations. Also, while I'm impressed they did seemingly pretty fluid mounted combat, it doesn't end up working. One hit knocks you off the horse, and unmounted (standard) combat is too far superior to be messing around on horseback anyway. I find myself moving through many areas wishing I could run faster, especially when retracing steps for a chest or to find/restart a climbing puzzle.  Climbing is generally impressively smooth. Honestly, I expected ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t like missing beams or constantly jumping 90 degrees off of my intended jump angle. That's actually quite rare, and usually my fault when it does happen. My only complaint here is when you can't jump onto or scale surfaces you definitely should be able to. Sometimes they're well under the standard jump height, with a gap in the walls/railing and everything. Just be aware there are well designed paths with generally obvious objects/textures, and you will be using them, even if it means going around or reconsidering dungeon rooms. Think more Drake's Fortune treasure puzzles, less Assassin's Creed.  This was a steal at $3. It's probably worth full price.

Darksiders is one of my favorite series. I played the loving crap out of the original DsII, so why should you? Well because IT IS FUN.  The Deathinitive edition is an improved version of the original. Includes all THE DLC, Better Graphics, Better Perfomance, and a NEW difficulty setting.  The gameplay is very similar to games like Devil May Cry, God of War, and Metal Gear Rising without being as punishing, while still remaining challenging on its own. You can Dial-a-Combo and destroy enemies, you can customize how you want to upgrade your skills, and equipment. This game has been compared to the Legend of Zelda, due to its combination of Open World, Dungeons and Puzzles. It is sorta like that but with better combat.  The graphics are amazing, the game is absolutely gorgeous. Most of the scenary is awe inspiring, the music is very memorable, and the voice acting is top notch ( Keith Szarabajka voice acting as the Crow Father is one of the absolute best in videogames). The Story is very similar to Spawn, if you ever read the comics.    Youy are certainly gonna have a good time with this one. It is one of the few AAA games that do never get old, due to its amazing visuals.

Finally, the version of the game that PC gaming deserved.  Updated graphics, integrated DLC, and a removal of that nasty Nightmare mode not many people really wanted to try...  The core game is stilll the core game, but the facelift goes a long way to enhancing the experience and the new items are a great addition to the boss fights. Some even scale with your level.  If you havent tried this game before, now is the time to jump in and swim or die.

UPDATED: 85/100   Runs extremely well on OUTDATED GTX 970 drivers. And with ♥♥♥♥♥♥ 6GB of ram, an old intel i7 ivy bridge 930, there's rarely any performance issues of any kind. Extremely rare to have frame rate drops. It does crash 1 out of 25 times you press ALT+TAB and only crashed once while opening the menu screen. Other than that, pretty much every issue has been fixed. Gameplay mechanics can be clunky but overall feel solid, organic and precise. Even GTA 5 runs 20x worse than DS2. Strays away from the generic and uninspired for the most part.   As you progress, the puzzles get boring, excessive and repetitive. There's some diversity but it just felt like the same crap over and over. There's still enough redeeming qualities to make it all enjoyable though.

Supposudly there was a crash issue on Day 1, but it's been fixed within a really quick window. So I can't hold it against the game.  As for a PROPER review.   This game is amazing. The characters and etc are created by Joe Madureira, a former cartoonist for Marvel. (It shows. Everything looks like it came right out of a comic.) The improved Graphics, textures, and lighting really help the game's comic book art style really stand out. (It's really great eye candy, and an example of a graphics update done right.)   The gameplay is unchanged from Darksiders 2, which is fine. Darksiders 2 is still a stand up when it comes to fantastic gameplay and level design. Though it is a bit lengthy, and some people can report growing tired around the third act.   I recommend this game a lot. Especially if you missed out the first time.

**Updated review** There've been three patches since this game was launched and they have addressed all the major complaints I've had. This version is now equal in stability and performance to the original release, and has slightly better graphics.   **Original Review** Was a big fan of Darksiders and Darksiders 2. I've played Darksiders all the way through maybe four or five times, and have played through Darksiders 2 three times prior to this remastered version.   Game immediately crashes upon starting. Have to reset settings and lower shadow quality. Why I need to not max out shadow quality on this graphical remastering makes no sense and should never have been launched with this issue. Started a new game and played through to the start of the cauldron. The camera feels 'shakier'. I had just started a new game on the original release a week ago, and re-launched it at the same starting area and it doesn't feel 'shaky'.  I had a cutscene that I couldn't use space to skip dialogue in. Was the first time I tried, so I thought maybe the button was changed. I pushed a bunch of buttons on the keyboard and mouse to no avail. When the cutscene finished, I spent the next ten minutes watching Death roll around and swinging as every queued up button press was executed post cutscene. After ten minutes I gave up and restarted the game.  Not happy with having to buy this for $6 because I don't own a combo pack. Overall after an hour or so of play I don't really see this as being worth it for someone who already has Darksiders 2. The graphical improvements are OK, but not worth spending money on. The only reason I am giving this game a thumbs up is that people buying this may help with getting a Darksiders 3 created, and that's a worthy goal.

Update: 11/22/15   So I've been playing this remaster edition of DS2 for a while and I'd like to say the game is actually better than what I thought previously. Although it had some really nasty bugs during its initial release, the developers had fixed them (at least in public beta) and now it runs very well on my laptop.  Current Issues: They are small and do npt pose serious problems to pro gamers.  a) On your way to the Drenchfort, there's a chance that you will fall infinitely and eventually die while you're riding the horse.  b) The Makers' chest area (Aylia) seem to have a resolution issue, since its texture was not smooth but made of chunks of small squares.  c) The game wouldn't stop running after you exit sometimes. It happens occasionally when you've played the game for several hours.  Let's talk about the pros:  Besides the apparent better texture and shaders, the gameplay system in this remastered edition is well-balanced. Old players won't really appreciate the beauty of it until the later stage of the game. I personally had complained about not being able to access my DLC weapons instantly before. Now I actually think it is a well-considered idea to let players gain access to them 'when the time is right'. Trust me, it makes the gameplay so much smoother, because you get to use better weapons and armors when you really need them.   Comment: Changed my opinion from Not Recommend to Recommended. Still, looking forward to seeing the developers improve the game further.

The game was pretty fun, and offered a lot of content, and things to collect. I do wish there were more side quests however. I will just quickly make my pros, and cons list. I will say first though, that i did not run into the glitches, and bad performance (for the most part) that i see in the forums,and reviews. My game ran above 100fps most of the time, and goes low as the 80s at worst, although there were a few small parts of the map that made my game drop into 40s out of nowehere, but that happend rarely. So here we go:  Pros: Fast, fluid, and fun combat. Tons of loot to collect. Lots of chests, and other secrets to uncover. A lot of different abilites to unlock, and use. Decent puzzles A decent story A really cool, and edgy main character. Some areas of the game were crisp, and beautiful to look at. A rather large variety of enemies A very good soundtrack  Cons: Not many side quests Some other areas were bland, and grey. Most boss battles we mindless mashing with no strategy, or puzzle involved.  Ending was dissapointing, and rushed.  Not many other likeable characters.  Camera angle was a bit wonky. The game felt mostly easy all the way through, except with a few bosses Horse riding was rather dull, and had clunky controls, and was rarely used/needed.  Well thats about how i feel about the game after beatingg the main story. I recommend this game to anyone who likes hack'n'slashers mixed with puzzles. The world is big, lots to do, and explore. It is a great game, but not without flaws. I can only imaine what my score would be if i did have all these glitches, and performance issues many gamers keep talking about. I for one, am glad i didn't run to any of it.   I give Darksiders 2 an 8/10.

This game is such a massive improvement over the first game. I thought the first game was just very average but this game is a genuinely good game that almost comes close to greatness. The combat and platforming is so much more fun in this game and it is the biggest improvement over the original. I loved the addition of the rpg elements and I loved the looting system that they introduced it just made you more invested in the gameplay. I also think that the dungeons are much better designed and more creative than in the original and I really enjoyed the open world in this game as well. Great soundtrack as well by the genius Jesper Kyd, it made the game feel a lot more epic. Great boss fights as well which is something that the first game lacked, I pretty much hated the boss fights in the original. The thing that stops this game from being great for me is my enjoyment level fluctuated a lot, there were times where I thought this game was amazing and i was having so much fun during those moments and at other times I thought the game slowed down a lot and I was having nowhere as much fun as those other sections of the game. I don’t think it’s a pacing issue I just think that some dungeons are much more fun than others. Also the story didn’t really grip me or made me interested into what was going on, I do think the story is a lot better than the original however.  7/10 (Good)

Stay as far away as possible from this version of the game. The stuttering is unbearable, even on minimum graphic settings on a PC that perfectly meets the recommended requirements. Crashes when changing the graphic setting, resulting in further multiple crashes before being able to restart the game again. Do the 'improved visuals' make up for the technical issues? Not even remotely. Where rocks used to look sharp and textured, they now appear like smooth plastic. Where colours used to be vibrant and appealing, they now changed to washed out hues that do no longer convey the same atmosphere. A few added grass blades are simply not enough. Do not invest any money in this edition of the game, rather buy the original if you do not own it yet. If you already do...just don't get this sorry excuse for a remake.
